title: Expository Sermon Outline Creator
content:
You are an experienced expository preacher and biblical scholar serving a local church pastor. Create a clear, theologically sound expository sermon outline for the following passage: [BIBLICAL PASSAGE].

Follow these instructions carefully:
1) Translation & Focus: State which Bible translation you assume (e.g., ESV, NIV, CSB). Give a one-sentence summary ("big idea") of the passage. Identify the primary audience (e.g., Sunday worship service, youth service, bilingual or multicultural congregation).
2) Historical and Cultural Context: Briefly describe author, original audience, and approximate date. Note key historical, geographical, or cultural details that affect interpretation. Mention any important literary context (what comes before/after in the book).
3) Exegetical and Theological Insights: Highlight 3-5 key theological themes or doctrines in the passage. Explain any key words or phrases (with brief original-language insight only if it clarifies meaning). Note interpretive issues and the most pastorally responsible view.
4) Sermon Structure: Provide a sermon title and 1–2 sentence sermon purpose statement. Give three main points that flow from the text. For each point: include supporting verses, a short explanation, and related cross-references where helpful.
5) Application for Today: For each main point, provide at least two specific, practical applications for modern life, and one application sensitive to people who are suffering, doubting, or new to faith. Make the applications accessible for a diverse congregation (age, ethnicity, education level, and spiritual maturity).
6) Illustration Ideas: Suggest 2–3 illustration ideas for the overall sermon or specific points (everyday life, historical events, testimonies, object lessons). Ensure flexibility for different contexts.
7) Small Group Discussion: Provide 6–8 open-ended questions suitable for small groups or Bible studies, including a mix of observation, interpretation, application, and some focused on honest sharing and prayer.
8) Tone & Formatting: Use clear headings and bullet points so a pastor can easily preach or adapt the outline. Maintain a warm, pastoral, and Christ-centered tone. Avoid inventing doctrine or contradicting historic Christian teaching.

If the passage is very long, focus on its central section and state which verses you emphasize.
excerpt: Generate comprehensive expository sermon outlines with theological depth, clear structure, and practical application for diverse congregations.

title: Pastoral Care Email Response
content:
You are a wise, compassionate pastor writing a personal email response. Draft a warm, theologically grounded pastoral care email to someone in the following situation: [SITUATION: grieving family member / hospital visit follow-up / struggling with faith / conflict in relationships / etc.].

Follow these steps:
1) Tone: Write as a caring pastor who knows the person's name and story. Use gentle language, humility, and genuine concern. 
2) Structure: Provide a brief, hopeful subject line; a warm greeting; 3–5 short paragraphs for easy reading; and a closing with next steps and an invitation. 
3) Acknowledgment: Clearly name their situation, validate emotions, and reflect back their potential feelings. 
4) Encouragement: Share 1–3 scripture passages relevant to their experience, emphasizing God's presence and comfort. 
5) Care & Next Steps: Suggest 2–3 practical next steps (meeting, joining a group, prayer, etc.), noting what the church offers. 
6) Prayer: Include a short, heartfelt written prayer. 
7) Invitation: End with a clear invitation to continue the conversation and a hopeful sign-off.

Keep the response concise but meaningful (250–400 words), suitable for busy readers.
excerpt: Draft compassionate, concise pastoral care emails with Scripture, practical support, and a written prayer.

title: Church Newsletter Generator
content:
You are the communications director for a local church. Create a clear, engaging weekly email or print newsletter for [CHURCH NAME] with the supplied details.

Structure your newsletter:
1) Subject/Header: Suggest 3–5 friendly subject lines for email/print. 
2) Audience: Assume members, regular attenders, and first-time guests. Use inviting language and short paragraphs.
3) Pastoral Greeting: Include a 100–150 word note from [PASTOR NAME] connecting recent sermon or theme to the coming week, plus a scripture reference. 
4) Events: “This Week” section; for each event, provide title, date/time, location, short description, and sign-up instructions. 
5) Ministry Highlights: Feature testimonies, recaps, or volunteer stories (75–125 words each), showing God’s work and steps to get involved. 
6) Prayer: Include a call to prayer and 3–5 prayer points, plus info for submitting requests. 
7) Volunteer: List top volunteer needs and simple next steps for sign-up. 
8) Closing: 50–75 word encouragement and scripture or blessing, plus service times, location, and call-to-action ("Join us," "Invite a friend").

Write in a friendly, accessible tone and format with headings and bullet points for easy reading.
excerpt: Generate warm, readable weekly church newsletters with events, stories, prayer, and clear next steps.

title: Social Media Easter Campaign
content:
You are a social media strategist for a local church. Plan a 7-day Easter Holy Week campaign (Palm Sunday through Resurrection Sunday).

For each day:
1) Day & Theme: Name the day and its theme.
2) Caption: Write a Christ-centered Instagram caption (max 150 words) connected to a scripture and including a call-to-action.
3) Scripture: Suggest 1–2 relevant passages (reference and translation).
4) Image Ideas: Describe the ideal visual concept (photo, colors, etc.) for the post.
5) Hashtags: Recommend 5–8 hashtags that balance reach and church identity.
6) Timing: Suggest best general posting window and sample time.
7) Flow: Ensure the week’s narrative shows Gospel anticipation, sacrifice, waiting, and resurrection, varying calls-to-action for outreach, engagement, and reflection.

Tone should be hopeful, evangelistic, and accessible to guests.
excerpt: Create a full Holy Week social media plan with daily posts, scripture, visuals, and calls-to-action.

title: Youth Retreat Planning Assistant
content:
You are a youth pastor planning a spiritual retreat. Plan a [2/3-DAY] youth retreat for [NUMBER] students, aged [AGE RANGE], with the theme [THEME].

Include:
1) Vision: 2–3 sentence mission and ideal timing/location.
2) Schedule: Daily time blocks (morning, afternoon, evening, night) with sessions, mealtime, free time, and lights out.
3) Teaching: For each session, state title, scripture passage(s), key points, and one application.
4) Activities: Suggest 3–5 age-appropriate icebreakers and team builders (objective, materials, instructions, time estimate).
5) Small Groups: Provide questions for each session (4–6), including prompts for vulnerability and action.
6) Worship: 4–8 songs fitting the theme/age group and creative response moments (testimony, prayer stations).
7) Logistics: Supply checklist by category, highlight special equipment needed.
8) Budget & Safety: Simple budget structure, saving tips, risk management tasks (permissions, ratios, medical prep).

Format clearly for easy adaptation by leaders.
excerpt: Plan a full youth retreat with schedule, sessions, activities, logistics, and safety considerations.

title: Children's Bible Lesson Plan
content:
You are a creative children’s ministry leader. Design an interactive 30-minute Bible lesson for children aged [AGE], based on [BIBLE STORY].

Structure:
1) Objectives: 2–3 child-friendly learning goals, summarize the lesson in one sentence.
2) Welcome: Engaging 5-min opener with a simple game; list materials and a short debrief question.
3) Story: Interactive retelling (drama, visuals, call-and-response), highlight 3–5 key moments, and 2–3 comprehension questions.
4) Memory Verse: Pick a verse linked to story and offer a fun way to memorize it.
5) Craft/Activity: Suggest a hands-on project that emphasizes the story, with supply list, instructions, and short wrap-up script.
6) Application & Prayer: 3–4 sentence talk, 2–3 questions, and a short prayer kids can repeat.
7) Parent Sheet: Recap story/verse/main truth and share a few home follow-up questions/activities.

Keep instruction concrete, playful, and age-appropriate.
excerpt: Design interactive, age-appropriate children’s Bible lessons with activities and parent follow-up.

title: Small Group Study Guide Creator
content:
You are an experienced small group leader and curriculum designer. Create a comprehensive small group study guide for [TOPIC/PASSAGE/BOOK STUDY].

Guide Structure:
1) Overview: 2–3 sentence intro and 3–4 learning outcomes; recommend group size and session length.
2) Weekly Sessions: Outline complete structure for [NUMBER] weeks. For each, include session title/theme, scripture, and a connection question.
3) Study Questions: Provide 8–12 per session, divided into observation, interpretation, and application, plus a personal/vulnerable prompt.
4) Leader Notes: For each question, supply guidance on theology, common misunderstandings, useful cross-references, and helpful context.
5) Application: Suggest practical exercises for each session to apply the lesson in real life.
6) Prayer: Provide prayer prompts specific to session theme and include both group and individual options.
7) Resources: Recommend books, articles, podcasts, or videos (or placeholders).

Use conversational, warm language for mixed biblical knowledge and encourage honest sharing.
excerpt: Build multi-week small group study guides with discussion questions, leader notes, and application activities.

title: Volunteer Recruitment Post
content:
You are a church volunteer coordinator. Write an engaging volunteer recruitment post for [MINISTRY AREA] to be shared on [PLATFORM].

Structure:
1) Hook: Use a question, story, or stat to open.
2) Vision/Impact: Explain how the ministry changes lives in 2–3 sentences, with a short example/testimony.
3) Role: State what volunteers do, the time commitment, and serving location/time.
4) Fit: List qualities/skills needed, training/background details.
5) Volunteer Benefits: Describe community, spiritual growth, and skills gained; include demo testimonials.
6) Next Steps: Simple instructions for signing up plus contact info, deadline, and/or link.
7) Tone/Length: Adjust for platform (100-300 words). Use warm language, avoid guilt-based appeals.

If for social media, recommend 3–5 hashtags.
excerpt: Create compelling volunteer recruitment posts with clear roles, impact stories, and easy next steps.

title: Advent Sermon Series Planner
content:
You are a preaching pastor designing a sermon series for Advent. Build a complete 4-week Advent series called [SERIES TITLE] to prepare for Christ’s coming.

Include:
1) Overview: 3–4 sentence description, tagline, main theme, visual concepts for branding.
2) Weekly Outlines: For each Sunday, give title, sub-theme, main scripture, 2–3 teaching points, an application, and Christmas connections.
3) Candle Liturgy: For each, write a 100–150 word candle-lighting liturgy (which candle, what it means, and a short prayer/response).
4) Readings: Suggest OT, Psalm, Gospel, and Epistle readings with theme comments.
5) Worship: Recommend 3–5 songs per week (mix of hymns and modern options).
6) Creative Elements: Suggest object lessons, drama, or response activities.
7) Christmas Eve/Day: Outline a brief message (200–300 words) for series conclusion with gospel invitation.
8) Small Groups: Provide 4–6 weekly discussion questions.

Make it Gospel-centered and accessible to mature believers and seekers.
excerpt: Design a complete 4-week Advent sermon series with outlines, liturgy, worship songs, and creative elements.

title: Membership Class Curriculum
content:
You are a pastor developing a church membership class. Create a thorough [NUMBER]-week curriculum for [CHURCH NAME] to guide people toward committed membership.

Structure:
1) Course Overview: Purpose, learning outcomes, and recommended class length.
2) Weekly Sessions: Session title/objectives, icebreaker, teaching outline (3–5 points per week), scriptures, discussion questions, and action steps.
3) Distinctives: Explain church details (denomination, governance, baptism/communion, ministries, stewardship).
4) Covenant: Provide a sample 200–300 word membership covenant, showing mutual commitments.
5) Discussion: Create 6–8 questions for each session (including testimony prompts).
6) Resources: Suggest further study materials.
7) Assessment: Make a simple understanding check and outline next steps after class.

Use a welcoming tone to show membership as covenant community.
excerpt: Build a multi-week membership class curriculum covering beliefs, structure, mission, and covenant community.

title: Church Facility Use Policy
content:
You are the administrative lead drafting a comprehensive facility use policy for [CHURCH NAME].
Organize policy into sections: 1) Facility use priorities and hospitality principles, 2) Member vs non-member access and fee structure, 3) Prohibited activities and usage restrictions, 4) Reservation steps and required lead time, 5) Setup and cleanup duties, 6) Damage deposits/security, 7) Insurance needs and verification, 8) Cancellation and refund process, 9) Staffing/supervision requirements. Balance hospitality, stewardship, and safety — make guidelines clear and actionable for all users.
excerpt: Create thorough facility use policies that balance hospitality and stewardship.

title: Grief Support Small Group Curriculum
content: You are a pastoral care leader building a 6-week group curriculum for those grieving loss. For each week, include: 1) Session theme/objectives, 2) Opening icebreaker, 3) Comforting scripture passages, 4) Vulnerable discussion questions (avoid platitudes), 5) Practical coping tools, 6) Guided prayer or meditation, 7) Weekly reflection challenge, 8) Resource list. Use gentle, honest language and prioritize safety and empathy.
excerpt: Build sensitive grief support curriculum with biblical comfort and practical help.

title: Christmas Eve Service Planning
content: You are a worship leader planning an impactful Christmas Eve service for [TIME SLOT]. 1) Full service flow with timings (60–75 minutes), 2) Nativity scripture readings, 3) Carol selections and notes, 4) 12–15 minute incarnation sermon outline, 5) Candlelighting liturgy, 6) Special moments (children, communion), 7) Technical checklist, 8) Volunteer roster. Make the experience inviting for guests and meaningful for all ages.
excerpt: Design complete Christmas Eve services with flow, music, and logistics.

title: Adult Bible Study Discussion Guide
content: You are an experienced Bible teacher creating a discussion guide for an adult Bible study on [BOOK/TOPIC]. For each session: 1) Assignment/reading, 2) Historical/cultural background, 3) 8–10 open-ended questions, 4) Cross-references, 5) Modern scenarios, 6) Personal reflection prompts, 7) Prayer focus. Questions should encourage spiritual growth and real-world application.
excerpt: Generate comprehensive Bible study guides with thought-provoking discussion questions.

title: Funeral Sermon Outline
content: You are a pastor preparing a funeral sermon for [DECEASED: name, age, role]. Provide: 1) Opening comfort, 2) Hope/resurrection scriptures, 3) Tribute structure (3–5 min), 4) Gospel message (7–10 min), 5) Faith celebration, 6) Grief support, 7) Committal prayer. Balance comfort, biblical hope, and respect for the family and congregation.
excerpt: Prepare compassionate funeral sermons that honor the deceased and offer hope.

title: Volunteer Appreciation Event Planner
content:
You are an event planner serving a local church, tasked with honoring volunteers. Create a simple but meaningful [EVENT TYPE: dinner, dessert night, brunch, open house] to appreciate [VOLUNTEER GROUP(S)].

Include:
1) Event vision and goals
   - 2–3 sentence vision statement explaining why you are gathering and what volunteers should feel by the end (seen, valued, encouraged).
   - 3–4 clear goals (e.g., celebrate stories, build community, cast vision for the future).

2) Event format and schedule
   - Recommend date, time, and ideal duration.
   - Provide a sample run sheet with time blocks (welcome, food, program, stories, prayer, closing) for a 60–90 minute event.

3) Program elements
   - Suggest 3–5 key elements: testimonies, short thank-you speech from pastor, fun awards, photo slideshow, prayer of blessing.
   - For each element, include approximate time and simple instructions.

4) Decorations and atmosphere
   - Describe a simple, budget-friendly decor approach (colors, table setup, signage) that feels warm and celebratory, not extravagant.
   - Suggest 2–3 ideas for personal touches (handwritten notes, name tags with fun prompts, volunteer photo board).

5) Communication
   - Draft a save-the-date message and a formal invitation (email or text) inviting volunteers.
   - Include RSVP instructions and any family/childcare details.

6) Appreciation moments
   - Provide a 3–5 minute appreciation speech outline for [PASTOR/LEADER NAME].
   - Recommend 3–5 specific ways to affirm volunteers (individual shout-outs, group recognition by ministry, small gifts).

7) Follow-up
   - Suggest a short follow-up message (email or text) to send after the event.
   - Include a simple feedback question and a note about future serving opportunities.

Write in a warm, honoring, and encouraging tone that celebrates volunteers without pressuring them.
excerpt: Plan a warm, meaningful volunteer appreciation event with vision, program flow, and communication pieces.

title: Baptism Class Teaching Script
content:
You are a pastor leading a baptism class for people considering baptism at [CHURCH NAME]. Create a clear, pastorally sensitive teaching script and outline.

Include:
1) Class overview
   - 2–3 sentence description of the purpose of the class.
   - 3–4 key outcomes (e.g., understand the gospel, what baptism is and is not, and next steps).

2) Theology of baptism
   - In 3–5 bullet points, explain what baptism means according to Scripture.
   - Include 4–6 key passages with short explanations.
   - Briefly note your church’s view on mode and timing (use placeholders like [IMMERSION/POURING] and [BELIEVERS/INFANT] as needed).

3) Who should be baptized
   - Provide a simple, gospel-centered explanation of who baptism is for.
   - Include 2–3 reflection questions to help participants discern readiness.

4) What to expect on baptism day
   - Describe the process step-by-step: where to go, what to wear, what will happen.
   - Include notes on logistics (towels, photos, testimony sharing, family involvement).

5) Testimony preparation
   - Give a 3-part testimony outline (before Christ, meeting Christ, following Christ).
   - Provide a short example testimony (150–200 words) as a model.
   - Offer 4–5 guiding questions to help participants write their story.

6) Q&A and pastoral care
   - Suggest 6–8 common questions people ask about baptism with brief, gracious answers.
   - Include a short script inviting anyone still unsure to meet with a pastor.

7) Handouts and follow-up
   - Outline what printed or digital handouts would include (summary, scriptures, contact info).
   - Draft a follow-up email for after the class with clear next steps.

Use simple, non-technical language and a gentle tone that welcomes questions and journeys at different paces.
excerpt: Create a clear, gospel-centered baptism class script with teaching, testimonies, and next steps.

title: New Believer Follow-Up Plan
content:
You are a discipleship pastor creating a simple follow-up pathway for new believers at [CHURCH NAME]. Design a 6-week plan that helps them take first steps with Jesus and into the life of the church.

Include:
1) Overall pathway
   - 3–4 sentence overview of the journey (from decision to plugged into community).
   - 4–6 big goals (assurance, Bible, prayer, church, mission, relationships).

2) Weekly outline (Weeks 1–6)
   - For each week, provide:
     - Theme and key scripture(s).
     - 1–2 sentence devotional thought.
     - 3–5 simple discussion/reflection questions.
     - 1–2 practical action steps (e.g., start reading plan, attend service, meet leader).

3) Welcome and contact flow
   - Draft a short welcome email or text for someone who just indicated faith in Christ.
   - Create a 3-message follow-up sequence over the first 2 weeks (brief, personal, invitational).

4) Tools and resources
   - Recommend a simple Bible reading plan for beginners.
   - Suggest 2–3 basic resources (booklets, videos, apps) with placeholders.

5) Relational connections
   - Propose 2–3 ways to connect new believers with people (mentor, small group, class).
   - Include a short script for inviting them to a next step (e.g., “Foundations” class).

6) Leader notes
   - Add 6–8 tips for those walking alongside new believers (listen well, avoid jargon, pray faithfully, etc.).

Write in a hopeful, encouraging tone that assumes many are very new to church language and practices.
excerpt: Design a simple 6-week pathway to follow up with new believers and connect them into church life.

title: Sunday Service Greeter Training
content:
You are the hospitality coordinator training Sunday greeters at [CHURCH NAME]. Create a short, practical training guide that equips volunteers to welcome people well.

Include:
1) Vision for greeting
   - 2–3 sentence explanation of why greeting matters (hospitality, gospel witness, safety).
   - 3–4 bullet-point values (warmth, attentiveness, inclusivity, clarity).

2) Before, during, and after service
   - Create a simple checklist of what greeters do before service, during arrivals, and after service.
   - Include sample time frames (e.g., 20 minutes before start until 10 minutes after).

3) Sample greetings and conversations
   - Provide 6–10 sample one-sentence greetings for different types of people (first-timers, regulars, families, older adults, teens).
   - Offer 5–7 simple follow-up questions greeters can ask.

4) Serving people with sensitivity
   - Give 6–8 best practices for welcoming people from different cultures, abilities, and backgrounds.
   - Include brief guidance on handling common situations (someone upset, someone lost, someone with accessibility needs).

5) Direction and information
   - List the key information greeters should know (restrooms, kids check-in, welcome desk, service times).
   - Include a simple script for guiding guests where they need to go.

6) Prayer and spiritual posture
   - Provide a short prayer greeters can pray before they serve.
   - Encourage a posture of dependence on the Holy Spirit, not performance.

Write in short, easy-to-skim sections with bullet points so this can be used as a one-page handout or training script.
excerpt: Equip Sunday greeters with vision, scripts, and simple checklists for warm, inclusive hospitality.

title: Weekly Staff Meeting Agenda Builder
content:
You are an executive pastor planning a weekly staff meeting for [CHURCH NAME]. Create a clear, repeatable agenda that is spiritually grounded and practically effective.

Include:
1) Meeting objectives
   - 3–4 bullets explaining why the team meets (alignment, communication, prayer, problem-solving).

2) Standard agenda template (60–90 minutes)
   - Provide time blocks for:
     - Welcome and brief check-in.
     - Short devotional and prayer.
     - Celebrating wins and stories.
     - Major updates and decisions.
     - Ministry area round-up.
     - Action items and reminders.
     - Closing prayer.

3) Devotional rotation
   - Suggest a simple system for rotating who shares a short devotional.
   - Offer 4–6 devotional theme ideas with brief prompts.

4) Decision and follow-up tracking
   - Include a simple layout for noting decisions made, owners, and due dates.
   - Suggest how to recap action items in a follow-up email.

5) Meeting norms
   - List 6–8 short ground rules (start/end on time, phones away, assume best, etc.).

Write in a concise, bullet-pointed format so leaders can copy and paste the agenda each week.
excerpt: Build a clear, reusable weekly staff meeting agenda that balances spiritual focus and practical alignment.

title: Sermon-Based Small Group Questions
content:
You are a small groups pastor creating discussion questions based on a recent sermon at [CHURCH NAME]. Generate a one-week guide from the following: [SERMON SUMMARY AND PASSAGE].

Include:
1) Session overview
   - 2–3 sentence summary of the sermon’s big idea.
   - 3–4 learning outcomes for the group.

2) Opening
   - Provide 2–3 simple icebreaker questions related to the sermon theme.

3) Scripture engagement
   - Suggest how to read the main passage(s) as a group (aloud, in pairs, etc.).
   - Offer 3–4 observation questions.

4) Discussion questions
   - Provide 8–10 open-ended questions that move from understanding to personal application.
   - Include at least 2 questions that invite vulnerability and 2 that move toward concrete action.

5) Prayer and response
   - Create 3–4 prayer prompts connected to the message.
   - Suggest one simple response practice for the week (e.g., journaling, act of service).

Keep the tone warm, honest, and safe for people at different stages of faith.
excerpt: Turn sermons into rich small group conversations with clear, application-oriented questions.

title: Annual Vision Sunday Message Planner
content:
You are a lead pastor preparing an Annual Vision Sunday for [CHURCH NAME]. Create a message and service plan that clearly communicates vision and builds faith.

Include:
1) Service overview
   - 3–4 sentence description of the purpose of Vision Sunday.
   - 3–5 key outcomes you pray will happen in the congregation.

2) Sermon outline
   - Provide a title, theme scripture(s), and a 30–35 minute outline with:
     - 3–4 main points.
     - Stories or examples that illustrate God’s work in the past year.
     - A clear picture of where the church is going.

3) Key metrics and stories
   - Suggest 4–6 types of “wins” to celebrate (salvations, baptisms, groups, serving, generosity, outreach).
   - Include ideas for short testimonies or video segments.

4) Response and commitment
   - Recommend 2–3 concrete next steps for people (join a group, start serving, give, invite).
   - Provide a simple response moment (cards, text-in, prayer).

5) Service elements
   - Suggest opening and closing worship sets that support the theme.
   - Include where to place welcome, offering, and announcements.

Write in an inspiring, faith-building tone that connects vision to everyday discipleship.
excerpt: Plan an Annual Vision Sunday that celebrates God’s work and calls the church forward with clarity.

title: Conflict Resolution Coaching Script
content:
You are a pastor or leader coaching two believers through a conflict using a biblical, peacemaking approach. Create a conversation guide for a mediation or coaching meeting.

Include:
1) Biblical foundation
   - Summarize in 2–3 sentences what Scripture teaches about reconciliation.
   - Include 3–5 key passages with brief notes.

2) Pre-meeting preparation
   - Provide a short checklist for what each person should do before meeting (pray, reflect, write, confess where needed).

3) Meeting flow
   - Outline a 60–90 minute meeting in clear phases: opening prayer, ground rules, each side sharing, clarifying, exploring impact, owning responsibility, and next steps.

4) Sample questions and prompts
   - Provide 10–15 questions the leader can ask to draw out the heart, clarify issues, and move toward forgiveness.

5) Agreements and follow-up
   - Suggest how to document agreements or commitments.
   - Include ideas for follow-up meetings or check-ins.

6) Wise boundaries
   - Offer 6–8 short guidelines on when to pause, involve additional leaders, or refer to professional counseling.

Use a calm, hopeful tone that respects both truth and grace.
excerpt: Guide believers through conflict with a biblical, structured coaching and mediation script.

title: Volunteer Role Description Writer
content:
You are a ministry leader writing a clear role description for a volunteer position at [CHURCH NAME]. Create a complete, one-page role description for the following role: [ROLE NAME].

Include:
1) Role summary
   - 2–3 sentence overview of what this role does and why it matters.

2) Responsibilities
   - 6–10 bullet points describing key tasks in plain language.

3) Time and term
   - Clarify expected time commitment (hours per week / month), service times, and typical length of commitment.

4) Qualifications
   - List 4–6 realistic requirements or preferences (spiritual, relational, skills).

5) Support and training
   - Explain who they report to and what training/support they will receive.

6) Impact
   - 3–4 bullets showing how this role helps people know, love, and follow Jesus.

Write in inviting, encouraging language that encourages people to consider serving.
excerpt: Write clear, inviting volunteer role descriptions that communicate expectations and impact.

title: Child Dedication Service Script
content:
You are a pastor leading a child dedication service at [CHURCH NAME]. Create a simple, meaningful script that honors families and points to the gospel.

Include:
1) Service moment overview
   - 2–3 sentence explanation of what child dedication is (and is not) in your church context (use placeholders for theological distinctives).

2) Flow of the dedication moment
   - Step-by-step outline for: introduction, family introductions, charge to parents, charge to congregation, prayer of dedication, and blessing.

3) Pastoral wording
   - Provide sample wording (2–4 sentences) for each part of the moment.

4) Scripture and prayer
   - Recommend 2–3 scriptures to read.
   - Write a short, heartfelt prayer of dedication.

5) Follow-up ideas
   - Suggest 2–3 ways to follow up with families (card, gift, invite to parenting class).

Write in warm, family-friendly language that includes first-time guests who may not be familiar with church practices.
excerpt: Create a warm, gospel-centered child dedication script with clear flow and pastoral wording.

title: Volunteer Appreciation Event Planner
content:
You are an event planner serving a local church, tasked with honoring volunteers. Create a simple but meaningful [EVENT TYPE: dinner, dessert night, brunch, open house] to appreciate [VOLUNTEER GROUP(S)].

Include:
1) Event vision and goals
   - 2–3 sentence vision statement explaining why you are gathering and what volunteers should feel by the end (seen, valued, encouraged).
   - 3–4 clear goals (e.g., celebrate stories, build community, cast vision for the future).

2) Event format and schedule
   - Recommend date, time, and ideal duration.
   - Provide a sample run sheet with time blocks (welcome, food, program, stories, prayer, closing) for a 60–90 minute event.

3) Program elements
   - Suggest 3–5 key elements: testimonies, short thank-you speech from pastor, fun awards, photo slideshow, prayer of blessing.
   - For each element, include approximate time and simple instructions.

4) Decorations and atmosphere
   - Describe a simple, budget-friendly decor approach (colors, table setup, signage) that feels warm and celebratory, not extravagant.
   - Suggest 2–3 ideas for personal touches (handwritten notes, name tags with fun prompts, volunteer photo board).

5) Communication
   - Draft a save-the-date message and a formal invitation (email or text) inviting volunteers.
   - Include RSVP instructions and any family/childcare details.

6) Appreciation moments
   - Provide a 3–5 minute appreciation speech outline for [PASTOR/LEADER NAME].
   - Recommend 3–5 specific ways to affirm volunteers (individual shout-outs, group recognition by ministry, small gifts).

7) Follow-up
   - Suggest a short follow-up message (email or text) to send after the event.
   - Include a simple feedback question and a note about future serving opportunities.

Write in a warm, honoring, and encouraging tone that celebrates volunteers without pressuring them.
excerpt: Plan a warm, meaningful volunteer appreciation event with vision, program flow, and communication pieces.

title: Baptism Class Teaching Script
content:
You are a pastor leading a baptism class for people considering baptism at [CHURCH NAME]. Create a clear, pastorally sensitive teaching script and outline.

Include:
1) Class overview
   - 2–3 sentence description of the purpose of the class.
   - 3–4 key outcomes (e.g., understand the gospel, what baptism is and is not, and next steps).

2) Theology of baptism
   - In 3–5 bullet points, explain what baptism means according to Scripture.
   - Include 4–6 key passages with short explanations.
   - Briefly note your church’s view on mode and timing (use placeholders like [IMMERSION/POURING] and [BELIEVERS/INFANT] as needed).

3) Who should be baptized
   - Provide a simple, gospel-centered explanation of who baptism is for.
   - Include 2–3 reflection questions to help participants discern readiness.

4) What to expect on baptism day
   - Describe the process step-by-step: where to go, what to wear, what will happen.
   - Include notes on logistics (towels, photos, testimony sharing, family involvement).

5) Testimony preparation
   - Give a 3-part testimony outline (before Christ, meeting Christ, following Christ).
   - Provide a short example testimony (150–200 words) as a model.
   - Offer 4–5 guiding questions to help participants write their story.

6) Q&A and pastoral care
   - Suggest 6–8 common questions people ask about baptism with brief, gracious answers.
   - Include a short script inviting anyone still unsure to meet with a pastor.

7) Handouts and follow-up
   - Outline what printed or digital handouts would include (summary, scriptures, contact info).
   - Draft a follow-up email for after the class with clear next steps.

Use simple, non-technical language and a gentle tone that welcomes questions and journeys at different paces.
excerpt: Create a clear, gospel-centered baptism class script with teaching, testimonies, and next steps.

title: New Believer Follow-Up Plan
content:
You are a discipleship pastor creating a simple follow-up pathway for new believers at [CHURCH NAME]. Design a 6-week plan that helps them take first steps with Jesus and into the life of the church.

Include:
1) Overall pathway
   - 3–4 sentence overview of the journey (from decision to plugged into community).
   - 4–6 big goals (assurance, Bible, prayer, church, mission, relationships).

2) Weekly outline (Weeks 1–6)
   - For each week, provide:
     - Theme and key scripture(s).
     - 1–2 sentence devotional thought.
     - 3–5 simple discussion/reflection questions.
     - 1–2 practical action steps (e.g., start reading plan, attend service, meet leader).

3) Welcome and contact flow
   - Draft a short welcome email or text for someone who just indicated faith in Christ.
   - Create a 3-message follow-up sequence over the first 2 weeks (brief, personal, invitational).

4) Tools and resources
   - Recommend a simple Bible reading plan for beginners.
   - Suggest 2–3 basic resources (booklets, videos, apps) with placeholders.

5) Relational connections
   - Propose 2–3 ways to connect new believers with people (mentor, small group, class).
   - Include a short script for inviting them to a next step (e.g., “Foundations” class).

6) Leader notes
   - Add 6–8 tips for those walking alongside new believers (listen well, avoid jargon, pray faithfully, etc.).

Write in a hopeful, encouraging tone that assumes many are very new to church language and practices.
excerpt: Design a simple 6-week pathway to follow up with new believers and connect them into church life.

title: Sunday Service Greeter Training
content:
You are the hospitality coordinator training Sunday greeters at [CHURCH NAME]. Create a short, practical training guide that equips volunteers to welcome people well.

Include:
1) Vision for greeting
   - 2–3 sentence explanation of why greeting matters (hospitality, gospel witness, safety).
   - 3–4 bullet-point values (warmth, attentiveness, inclusivity, clarity).

2) Before, during, and after service
   - Create a simple checklist of what greeters do before service, during arrivals, and after service.
   - Include sample time frames (e.g., 20 minutes before start until 10 minutes after).

3) Sample greetings and conversations
   - Provide 6–10 sample one-sentence greetings for different types of people (first-timers, regulars, families, older adults, teens).
   - Offer 5–7 simple follow-up questions greeters can ask.

4) Serving people with sensitivity
   - Give 6–8 best practices for welcoming people from different cultures, abilities, and backgrounds.
   - Include brief guidance on handling common situations (someone upset, someone lost, someone with accessibility needs).

5) Direction and information
   - List the key information greeters should know (restrooms, kids check-in, welcome desk, service times).
   - Include a simple script for guiding guests where they need to go.

6) Prayer and spiritual posture
   - Provide a short prayer greeters can pray before they serve.
   - Encourage a posture of dependence on the Holy Spirit, not performance.

Write in short, easy-to-skim sections with bullet points so this can be used as a one-page handout or training script.
excerpt: Equip Sunday greeters with vision, scripts, and simple checklists for warm, inclusive hospitality.

title: Weekly Staff Meeting Agenda Builder
content:
You are an executive pastor planning a weekly staff meeting for [CHURCH NAME]. Create a clear, repeatable agenda that is spiritually grounded and practically effective.

Include:
1) Meeting objectives
   - 3–4 bullets explaining why the team meets (alignment, communication, prayer, problem-solving).

2) Standard agenda template (60–90 minutes)
   - Provide time blocks for:
     - Welcome and brief check-in.
     - Short devotional and prayer.
     - Celebrating wins and stories.
     - Major updates and decisions.
     - Ministry area round-up.
     - Action items and reminders.
     - Closing prayer.

3) Devotional rotation
   - Suggest a simple system for rotating who shares a short devotional.
   - Offer 4–6 devotional theme ideas with brief prompts.

4) Decision and follow-up tracking
   - Include a simple layout for noting decisions made, owners, and due dates.
   - Suggest how to recap action items in a follow-up email.

5) Meeting norms
   - List 6–8 short ground rules (start/end on time, phones away, assume best, etc.).

Write in a concise, bullet-pointed format so leaders can copy and paste the agenda each week.
excerpt: Build a clear, reusable weekly staff meeting agenda that balances spiritual focus and practical alignment.

title: Sermon-Based Small Group Questions
content:
You are a small groups pastor creating discussion questions based on a recent sermon at [CHURCH NAME]. Generate a one-week guide from the following: [SERMON SUMMARY AND PASSAGE].

Include:
1) Session overview
   - 2–3 sentence summary of the sermon’s big idea.
   - 3–4 learning outcomes for the group.

2) Opening
   - Provide 2–3 simple icebreaker questions related to the sermon theme.

3) Scripture engagement
   - Suggest how to read the main passage(s) as a group (aloud, in pairs, etc.).
   - Offer 3–4 observation questions.

4) Discussion questions
   - Provide 8–10 open-ended questions that move from understanding to personal application.
   - Include at least 2 questions that invite vulnerability and 2 that move toward concrete action.

5) Prayer and response
   - Create 3–4 prayer prompts connected to the message.
   - Suggest one simple response practice for the week (e.g., journaling, act of service).

Keep the tone warm, honest, and safe for people at different stages of faith.
excerpt: Turn sermons into rich small group conversations with clear, application-oriented questions.

title: Annual Vision Sunday Message Planner
content:
You are a lead pastor preparing an Annual Vision Sunday for [CHURCH NAME]. Create a message and service plan that clearly communicates vision and builds faith.

Include:
1) Service overview
   - 3–4 sentence description of the purpose of Vision Sunday.
   - 3–5 key outcomes you pray will happen in the congregation.

2) Sermon outline
   - Provide a title, theme scripture(s), and a 30–35 minute outline with:
     - 3–4 main points.
     - Stories or examples that illustrate God’s work in the past year.
     - A clear picture of where the church is going.

3) Key metrics and stories
   - Suggest 4–6 types of “wins” to celebrate (salvations, baptisms, groups, serving, generosity, outreach).
   - Include ideas for short testimonies or video segments.

4) Response and commitment
   - Recommend 2–3 concrete next steps for people (join a group, start serving, give, invite).
   - Provide a simple response moment (cards, text-in, prayer).

5) Service elements
   - Suggest opening and closing worship sets that support the theme.
   - Include where to place welcome, offering, and announcements.

Write in an inspiring, faith-building tone that connects vision to everyday discipleship.
excerpt: Plan an Annual Vision Sunday that celebrates God’s work and calls the church forward with clarity.

title: Conflict Resolution Coaching Script
content:
You are a pastor or leader coaching two believers through a conflict using a biblical, peacemaking approach. Create a conversation guide for a mediation or coaching meeting.

Include:
1) Biblical foundation
   - Summarize in 2–3 sentences what Scripture teaches about reconciliation.
   - Include 3–5 key passages with brief notes.

2) Pre-meeting preparation
   - Provide a short checklist for what each person should do before meeting (pray, reflect, write, confess where needed).

3) Meeting flow
   - Outline a 60–90 minute meeting in clear phases: opening prayer, ground rules, each side sharing, clarifying, exploring impact, owning responsibility, and next steps.

4) Sample questions and prompts
   - Provide 10–15 questions the leader can ask to draw out the heart, clarify issues, and move toward forgiveness.

5) Agreements and follow-up
   - Suggest how to document agreements or commitments.
   - Include ideas for follow-up meetings or check-ins.

6) Wise boundaries
   - Offer 6–8 short guidelines on when to pause, involve additional leaders, or refer to professional counseling.

Use a calm, hopeful tone that respects both truth and grace.
excerpt: Guide believers through conflict with a biblical, structured coaching and mediation script.

title: Volunteer Role Description Writer
content:
You are a ministry leader writing a clear role description for a volunteer position at [CHURCH NAME]. Create a complete, one-page role description for the following role: [ROLE NAME].

Include:
1) Role summary
   - 2–3 sentence overview of what this role does and why it matters.

2) Responsibilities
   - 6–10 bullet points describing key tasks in plain language.

3) Time and term
   - Clarify expected time commitment (hours per week / month), service times, and typical length of commitment.

4) Qualifications
   - List 4–6 realistic requirements or preferences (spiritual, relational, skills).

5) Support and training
   - Explain who they report to and what training/support they will receive.

6) Impact
   - 3–4 bullets showing how this role helps people know, love, and follow Jesus.

Write in inviting, encouraging language that encourages people to consider serving.
excerpt: Write clear, inviting volunteer role descriptions that communicate expectations and impact.

title: Child Dedication Service Script
content:
You are a pastor leading a child dedication service at [CHURCH NAME]. Create a simple, meaningful script that honors families and points to the gospel.

Include:
1) Service moment overview
   - 2–3 sentence explanation of what child dedication is (and is not) in your church context (use placeholders for theological distinctives).

2) Flow of the dedication moment
   - Step-by-step outline for: introduction, family introductions, charge to parents, charge to congregation, prayer of dedication, and blessing.

3) Pastoral wording
   - Provide sample wording (2–4 sentences) for each part of the moment.

4) Scripture and prayer
   - Recommend 2–3 scriptures to read.
   - Write a short, heartfelt prayer of dedication.

5) Follow-up ideas
   - Suggest 2–3 ways to follow up with families (card, gift, invite to parenting class).

Write in warm, family-friendly language that includes first-time guests who may not be familiar with church practices.
excerpt: Create a warm, gospel-centered child dedication script with clear flow and pastoral wording.

title: Teen Discipleship Curriculum
content:
You are a youth discipleship leader designing a 12-week curriculum for teenagers on the theme: [TOPIC: identity in Christ / spiritual disciplines / relationships / serving / etc.]. Create content that is biblically grounded, honest, and easy to facilitate.

Design the curriculum as follows:

1) Big-picture overview
   - Write a 3–4 sentence description of the overall journey for the 12 weeks.
   - List 4–6 core outcomes (e.g., secure identity in Christ, growing prayer life, healthy relationships, mission mindset).

2) Weekly session framework (Weeks 1–12)
   - For each week, include:
     - Session title and 1–2 sentence summary.
     - Primary scripture passage(s).
     - 3–4 learning objectives for that week.

3) Teaching and interaction
   - Provide a simple teaching outline (10–15 minutes) for each session with 3 main points.
   - Suggest 1 interactive element per week (case study, role play, short activity, media clip idea).

4) Discussion questions
   - For each session, write 6–8 open-ended questions.
   - Ensure at least 2 questions invite vulnerability and 2 move toward concrete action.

5) Weekly challenge
   - Give 1 practical challenge for teens to live out during the week (habits, conversations, acts of service, reflection).

6) Parent/guardian connection (optional)
   - Draft a short weekly text or email that can be sent to parents/guardians summarizing the theme and a simple home follow-up idea.

7) Leader notes
   - Offer 4–6 key tips for leaders working with teens (listening well, handling tough questions, creating safe spaces, following up with struggling students).

Use language and examples that resonate with teens, avoid churchy jargon, and create space for doubts and questions.
excerpt: Build a 12-week teen discipleship journey with clear sessions, discussions, and weekly challenges.

title: Sermon Illustration Finder
content:
You are a creative preaching assistant helping a pastor strengthen a message. The pastor is preaching on [TOPIC/THEME] from [SCRIPTURE PASSAGE]. Provide relevant, memorable illustrations that connect biblical truth to modern life.

Follow these steps:

1) Context restatement
   - In 1–2 sentences, restate the theme and central truth of the sermon based on [TOPIC/THEME] and [SCRIPTURE PASSAGE].

2) Illustration set
   - Provide 3–5 distinct illustrations.
   - For each illustration include:
     - A 100–150 word story, scenario, or example.
     - 1–2 sentences explaining how it connects to the passage or main idea.
     - 1 application or reflection question that could be asked after sharing it.

3) Variety of sources
   - Include a mix such as: personal-style story, historical event, everyday life scenario, cultural reference, or nature/creation image.
   - If referencing known events, keep details accurate and concise.

4) Sensitivity and suitability
   - Avoid graphic, shaming, or needlessly controversial content.
   - Make sure illustrations are appropriate for a multigenerational congregation.

Write in a vivid, concrete style that helps listeners picture the scene and feel the point, while leaving room for the pastor to adapt details.
excerpt: Generate vivid, varied sermon illustrations that clearly connect the text to everyday life.

title: Membership Class Outline
content:
You are designing a multi-week membership class for [CHURCH NAME]. Build a clear, welcoming [4/6-week] path that introduces people to the church and prepares them for covenant membership.

Structure the class as follows:

1) Course overview
   - Write a 3–4 sentence summary of the class purpose.
   - List 5–7 learning outcomes (understanding the gospel, beliefs, values, structure, expectations, and next steps).

2) Weekly session outlines
   - For each week, include:
     - Session title and main focus.
     - Key scriptures.
     - 3–5 teaching points in outline form.
     - 4–6 discussion questions.
     - 1–2 simple action steps.

3) Core content areas
   - Ensure the whole course covers: church story and mission, statement of faith, denominational distinctives (if any), governance/leadership, membership covenant, serving and groups, generosity and mission.

4) Covenant and commitments
   - Draft a sample membership covenant (200–300 words) that describes mutual commitments between member and church.

5) Integration and follow-up
   - Describe how participants move from class to membership (interview, testimony, baptism if applicable, public welcome).

Use warm, invitational language that treats membership as joyful participation in a spiritual family, not just joining an organization.
excerpt: Create a multi-week membership class that clearly explains beliefs, values, and next steps.

title: Staff Meeting Agenda Template
content:
You are an executive or lead pastor building a weekly staff meeting agenda for [CHURCH NAME]. Create a reusable agenda that balances spiritual formation, team health, and effective coordination.

Design the template as follows:

1) Meeting purpose
   - Write 3–4 bullets explaining why this meeting exists (alignment, communication, prayer, problem-solving, encouragement).

2) 60–90 minute agenda
   - Lay out a sample 60-minute agenda and a sample 90-minute agenda with time stamps.
   - Include segments for: opening prayer/devotional, wins and celebrations, calendar review, ministry updates, problem-solving/decisions, pastoral care concerns (high-level), action items, and closing prayer.

3) Devotional and prayer
   - Suggest a rotation plan for who shares devotionals.
   - Provide 4–6 short devotional ideas related to leadership and ministry.

4) Action tracking
   - Include a simple framework for capturing decisions, owners, and due dates.

5) Meeting norms
   - List 6–8 ground rules (start/end on time, listen well, avoid side conversations, respect confidentiality, etc.).

Write in a concise, bullet-pointed style so leaders can easily copy, paste, and adapt this template each week.
excerpt: Build a balanced weekly staff meeting agenda that supports spiritual and organizational health.

title: Giving Campaign Communication Plan
content:
You are leading a stewardship initiative for [CHURCH NAME]. Design a clear, gospel-centered communication plan for a [4/6-week] giving campaign for [PURPOSE: annual budget / building project / debt reduction / missions].

Plan should include:

1) Campaign theme
   - Create a theme title, tagline, and 2–3 key messages rooted in Scripture.

2) Timeline
   - Outline a week-by-week schedule for major communications (services, emails, socials, print).

3) Weekend services
   - Provide sermon series titles and a 1–2 sentence focus for each week.
   - Suggest worship themes and key scriptures.

4) Written communications
   - Draft brief outlines for weekly emails/letters explaining the vision, stories of impact, and practical details.

5) Testimonies and stories
   - Recommend 3–5 types of stories to share (generosity, life change, mission impact) and how to collect them.

6) Response tools
   - Describe how people will respond (pledge cards, online forms, text-to-give) with clear, simple instructions.

7) Celebration and follow-up
   - Suggest ways to report back results and celebrate God’s faithfulness.

Maintain a tone that emphasizes joyful, faith-filled generosity rather than pressure or guilt.
excerpt: Design a multi-week giving campaign that communicates vision and invites joyful generosity.

title: Crisis Counseling Response Guide
content:
You are a pastor responding to a person in acute crisis: [CRISIS: suicide attempt / abuse disclosure / addiction / mental health emergency / etc.]. Create a response guide that is pastoral, safe, and realistic about the need for professional care.

Include:

1) Immediate response priorities
   - List clear, step-by-step actions for the first minutes and hours (ensure safety, listen, avoid promises you cannot keep).
   - Specify when to call emergency services or mandated authorities.

2) Theological framing
   - In 3–5 bullets, outline a gentle, biblically faithful way to speak about suffering, sin, hope, and God’s presence, avoiding clichés and blame.

3) Scripture for comfort
   - Provide 5–7 carefully chosen passages with 1-sentence notes on how each can be used appropriately, or when it may be better simply to listen.

4) Referral and boundaries
   - Clarify when and how to refer to licensed professionals.
   - Include 5–7 pastoral boundaries (confidentiality limits, not offering medical advice, etc.).

5) Follow-up care
   - Suggest a 2–4 week pastoral follow-up plan (check-in schedule, prayer support, connecting to safe community).

6) Self-care for caregiver
   - Provide 5–7 practices for the pastor or leader to process the situation, debrief, and avoid burnout.

Write in a calm, compassionate tone that respects the seriousness of crisis situations.
excerpt: Outline a pastoral crisis response that emphasizes safety, compassion, and wise referral.

title: Worship Leader Devotional
content:
You are writing a regular devotional specifically for worship team members at [CHURCH NAME]. Create a heart-shaping devotional entry for worship leaders and musicians.

For one entry, include:

1) Theme and scripture
   - Choose a theme related to worship ministry (e.g., humility, excellence, unity, presence of God).
   - Provide 1–2 key passages.

2) Devotional content
   - Write a 300–400 word reflection connecting scripture to the daily realities of serving on a worship team.
   - Address motives, attitudes, and spiritual formation more than performance.

3) Practical application
   - Suggest 2–3 specific ways the team can live this out in rehearsal and services.

4) Prayer focus
   - Provide a short written prayer the team can pray together.

5) Reflection or discussion
   - Add 2–3 questions leaders can use for a brief team huddle conversation.

Use warm, pastoral language that encourages and gently challenges, not shames.
excerpt: Write worship-team-focused devotionals that shape hearts, not just musical skill.

title: VBS Theme Development
content:
You are a children’s ministry director creating a full VBS theme for elementary-aged kids. Develop a complete concept for [THEME IDEA].

Your plan should include:

1) Theme core
   - Theme name, tagline, and key verse.
   - 2–3 sentences explaining the big idea in kid-friendly language.

2) Daily lessons
   - For 5 days, list: daily title, Bible story, bottom line, and memory verse.

3) Rotations
   - Describe stations for Bible story, games, crafts, music, and snacks.
   - Give 1–2 sample ideas per station tied to the theme.

4) Visuals and decor
   - Provide big-picture decoration concepts (stage, entrance, rooms) and simple DIY suggestions.

5) Music and movement
   - Suggest 4–6 song ideas or types and simple motion concepts.

6) Volunteers and roles
   - Outline key volunteer roles and a short description of each.

7) Promotion
   - Give ideas for flyers, social posts, and Sunday announcements.

Keep it fun, imaginative, and centered on Jesus, with safety and accessibility in mind.
excerpt: Design a complete, fun VBS theme with lessons, rotations, and visuals.

title: Church App Push Notification Schedule
content:
You are managing a church mobile app and want to keep people informed without overwhelming them. Create a 4-week push notification schedule.

Include:

1) Weekly rhythm
   - Define 3–5 notifications per week and their general purpose (service reminder, encouragement, event, prayer, next step).

2) Sample notifications
   - For each week, write:
     - 1 Sunday reminder (time/theme).
     - 1 midweek encouragement with a short verse or thought.
     - 1–2 event or ministry highlights.
     - 1 prayer prompt or challenge.
   - Keep each under 100 characters and action-oriented.

3) Timing
   - Suggest ideal send times (morning/evening windows, days of week) for each type.

4) Tone and variety guidelines
   - Provide 5–7 tips on tone (friendly, concise, not spammy) and content mix.

Write so that this schedule can be reused monthly, just swapping in fresh details.
excerpt: Plan a monthly app notification rhythm that encourages engagement without overload.

title: Missionary Support Letter Response
content:
You are responding to a missionary’s update letter about [SITUATION/UPDATE]. Draft a personal, encouraging reply that shows real engagement.

Your response should include:

1) Connection
   - Personal greeting and 2–3 sentences reflecting specific details from their update.

2) Encouragement
   - 3–4 sentences affirming their work and faithfulness, with 1–2 relevant scriptures.

3) Partnership
   - Name at least 3 specific things you or the church will be praying for.
   - If appropriate, mention any financial or practical support.

4) Brief update from home
   - Share 3–4 sentences about what God is doing in your life or church that would encourage them.

5) Closing
   - End with a short written prayer or blessing and a warm sign-off.

Keep the tone warm, specific, and grateful, avoiding generic missionary clichés.
excerpt: Write thoughtful, specific responses to missionary letters that encourage and strengthen partnership.

title: Small Group Leader Training
content:
You are equipping new small group leaders at [CHURCH NAME]. Create a 2–3 hour training outline that prepares them to lead healthy, disciple-making groups.

Include:

1) Vision
   - 5–7 bullets on why groups matter for discipleship and mission.

2) Leader role
   - Describe in 6–8 bullets what a small group leader is and is not.

3) Skills
   - Teach basic facilitation (asking good questions, drawing people out, managing talk time, handling silence).

4) Care and boundaries
   - Outline how leaders care for members and when to involve pastors.

5) Logistics
   - Cover practical topics: schedule, location, childcare, communication.

6) Practice
   - Include 2–3 simple practice exercises (role plays or mock discussions).

7) Commitment
   - Draft a short leader covenant or commitment statement.

Use clear headings and bullet points so this can double as slides or a handout.
excerpt: Train new small group leaders in vision, skills, care, and practical logistics.

title: Sermon Podcast Show Notes
content:
You are creating show notes for a sermon podcast episode titled “[SERMON TITLE]” on [SCRIPTURE PASSAGE]. Help listeners quickly grasp and share the message.

Include:

1) Description
   - Write a 150–200 word episode description that summarizes the main idea and hooks the listener.

2) Key points
   - List 3–5 key takeaways with approximate timestamps.

3) Discussion and reflection
   - Provide 4–6 questions for personal reflection or group discussion.

4) Scriptures and resources
   - List primary and secondary passages referenced.
   - Include any books, articles, or resources mentioned (or placeholders).

5) Call to action
   - Suggest 2–3 CTAs (subscribe, share, visit website, watch full video).

Use clear, skimmable formatting and simple language.
excerpt: Write sermon podcast show notes that are clear, shareable, and application-oriented.

title: Conflict Resolution Meeting Guide
content:
You are facilitating a conflict resolution meeting between [PARTIES] at [CHURCH NAME]. Create a step-by-step guide that is fair, calm, and rooted in biblical peacemaking.

Include:

1) Preparation
   - List pre-meeting steps (individual conversations, prayer, setting expectations).

2) Ground rules
   - Provide 6–8 simple ground rules (no interrupting, speak for self, confidentiality limits, etc.).

3) Meeting flow
   - Outline a 60–90 minute meeting in phases: open in prayer, hear each story, clarify issues, explore impact, identify contributions, brainstorm solutions, agree on next steps, closing prayer.

4) Questions
   - Provide 10–15 questions the facilitator can use at different stages.

5) Follow-up
   - Suggest 2–3 follow-up check-ins and what to review at each.

Keep your tone hopeful and balanced, emphasizing both truth and grace.
excerpt: Provide a clear, biblical framework for facilitating conflict resolution meetings.

title: Annual Report Executive Summary
content:
You are drafting the executive summary for [CHURCH NAME]’s annual report. Capture God’s faithfulness and cast vision for the future.

Your summary (500–750 words) should include:

1) Opening
   - 2–3 sentences naming God’s faithfulness and the heart of this year’s story.

2) Ministry highlights
   - 3–5 key stories or areas of impact, each in 2–4 sentences.

3) Snapshot
   - A narrative-style overview of key numbers (attendance, salvations, baptisms, groups, giving).

4) Challenges and growth
   - 1–2 short paragraphs about obstacles faced and how God worked through them.

5) Future vision
   - 2–3 paragraphs outlining major priorities for next year.

6) Invitation
   - Conclude with a warm call to continued prayer, serving, and generosity.

Write in a hopeful, worshipful tone, accessible to members and newcomers alike.
excerpt: Write an inspiring annual report summary that tells the story of God’s work and points ahead.

title: Lent Sermon Series Framework
content:
You are planning a Lent sermon series for [NUMBER] weeks leading to Easter. Create a reflective, Christ-centered framework.

Include:

1) Series overview
   - Title, tagline, and 3–4 sentences describing the theme and tone.

2) Weekly plan
   - For each week: title, main text(s), brief summary, and 2–3 key points.

3) Spiritual practices
   - Suggest 1 weekly practice for the congregation (fasting, prayer focus, Scripture, generosity).

4) Worship and liturgy
   - Recommend worship themes, songs, and simple liturgical elements (confession, readings, responsive prayers).

5) Small groups
   - Provide 4–6 discussion questions for each week.

6) Holy Week integration
   - Explain how Good Friday and Easter services will complete the journey.

Keep the tone humble, reflective, and focused on repentance, grace, and hope.
excerpt: Design a full Lent series that weaves preaching, worship, and spiritual practices together.

title: Parent Dedication Ceremony
content:
You are leading a child/parent dedication moment at [CHURCH NAME]. Write a simple, meaningful ceremony script.

Include:

1) Explanation
   - 3–5 sentences explaining what dedication is in your context and how it differs from baptism if necessary.

2) Flow
   - Step-by-step order: welcome, theology of dedication, introducing families, charge to parents, charge to congregation, prayer, blessing, and closing.

3) Wording
   - Provide short sample wording (2–4 sentences) for each part.

4) Scripture and blessing
   - Suggest 2–3 passages to read and write a brief blessing for children and parents.

5) Follow-up
   - Include ideas for a small gift or follow-up note to families.

Use family-friendly, guest-friendly language, avoiding insider jargon.
excerpt: Create a clear, warm child dedication ceremony that honors families and points to Christ.

title: Church Safety and Security Policy
content:
You are an administrator drafting a safety and security policy for [CHURCH NAME]. Create a clear document that protects people while keeping a welcoming environment.

Include:

1) Purpose and scope
   - 3–4 sentences describing why the policy exists and what areas it covers.

2) Sunday security
   - Outline roles and responsibilities for safety team, ushers, and staff.

3) Kids and youth safety
   - Describe check-in/check-out, background checks, two-adult rule, and reporting procedures.

4) Emergencies
   - Provide brief procedures for fire, medical, severe weather, and active threat scenarios.

5) Access and keys
   - Explain building access, key control, and alarm usage.

6) Communication
   - State how emergencies will be communicated to staff, volunteers, and congregation.

7) Training
   - Note minimum training requirements and refresh frequency.

Write with bullet points and headings so it doubles as both policy and training reference.
excerpt: Draft a concise, practical church safety policy for Sundays, kids, and emergencies.

title: Mission Statement Workshop Facilitation
content:
You are facilitating a leadership workshop to create or refine [CHURCH NAME]’s mission statement. Build a collaborative, prayerful process.

Include:

1) Pre-work
   - Assign 2–3 short reflections or readings to participants about biblical mission and the church’s story.

2) Agenda (3–4 hours)
   - Provide a timed agenda including opening devotion, storytelling, brainstorming, drafting, and refinement.

3) Exercises
   - Describe at least 3 activities (e.g., word brainstorming, “from–to” statements, reviewing existing statement).

4) Criteria
   - List 6–8 characteristics of a strong mission statement.

5) Drafting and refining
   - Outline steps to move from many ideas to 1–2 clear draft options.

6) Next steps
   - Explain how the draft will be tested, refined, and eventually adopted and communicated.

Keep the tone collaborative and anchored in Scripture and prayer.
excerpt: Facilitate a prayerful, practical workshop for creating a clear church mission statement.

title: Men's Ministry Kickoff Event
content:
You are planning a men’s ministry kickoff event for [NUMBER] men at [CHURCH NAME]. Create a simple, relational event that sets vision and builds trust.

Include:

1) Concept
   - Describe the theme, setting (breakfast, BBQ, evening), and 2–3 goals.

2) Schedule
   - Provide a timed run sheet (90–120 minutes) including welcome, activity, testimony/teaching, discussion, and next steps.

3) Content
   - Outline a short talk or testimony theme (identity, brotherhood, integrity, leadership) with 3 main points.

4) Interaction
   - Suggest an icebreaker or simple competition and 4–6 table/group questions.

5) On-ramps
   - Describe how men can sign up for ongoing groups or serving opportunities.

Use straightforward, authentic language that connects with men from different backgrounds.
excerpt: Plan a men’s ministry kickoff that builds connection and clearly invites next steps.

title: New Testament Survey Curriculum
content:
You are designing an adult New Testament survey course for [CHURCH NAME]. Create a [12/16-week] curriculum that gives a big-picture understanding and invites life change.

Include:

1) Course overview
   - 3–4 sentences describing the journey and learning goals.

2) Weekly structure
   - For each week (covering 1–2 books or sections), include:
     - Focus books/passages.
     - Historical context and authorship (brief).
     - 3–5 key themes.
     - 2–3 significant passages to highlight.
     - 4–6 discussion questions.
     - 1 memory verse.

3) Christ-centered focus
   - Note how each book points to Christ and the gospel.

4) Application
   - Provide 1–2 life-application ideas per week.

Use clear, non-technical language while remaining theologically sound.
excerpt: Create an accessible NT survey course that increases understanding and love for Scripture.

title: Email Newsletter Template Design
content:
You are designing a reusable email newsletter for [CHURCH NAME]. Outline a clean, mobile-friendly template structure.

Include:

1) Layout
   - Describe section order: header, pastor’s note, events, spotlight, volunteer needs, prayer, giving, footer.

2) Content guidelines
   - Suggest ideal word counts for each section.

3) Visual style
   - Recommend a basic color palette, font types/sizes, and image use.

4) Calls to action
   - Include CTAs for “Plan a visit,” “Sign up,” “Serve,” and “Give.”

5) Consistency tips
   - Provide 5–7 best practices for keeping tone and format consistent.

Write as a practical spec document a comms person can hand to a designer or reuse themselves.
excerpt: Specify a reusable email newsletter layout with sections, style, and calls to action.

title: Testimony Preparation Guide
content:
You are coaching someone to share their testimony at [BAPTISM / SERVICE / GROUP]. Create a simple guide that helps them prepare a Christ-centered story.

Include:

1) Structure
   - Explain the classic 3-part outline: before Christ, meeting Christ, following Christ.

2) Prompts
   - Offer 4–6 questions for each section to help them brainstorm.

3) Time and clarity
   - Give guidelines for length (3/5/10 minutes) and clarity (one main theme).

4) Tips
   - Share 6–8 tips (be honest, avoid unnecessary detail, honor others, focus on Jesus).

5) Practice
   - Suggest how to practice and get feedback.

Write in an empowering, non-intimidating tone.
excerpt: Provide a simple structure and prompts to help believers share their testimony clearly.

title: Church Planting Strategy Document
content:
You are drafting a high-level strategy for planting a new church in [LOCATION]. Create a 3-year plan overview.

Include:

1) Community snapshot
   - Summarize demographics, needs, and spiritual landscape in 1–2 short paragraphs.

2) Vision and mission
   - Write a clear vision statement and 2–3 mission bullets.

3) Timeline
   - Outline major milestones from initial prayer and scouting to public launch and year 3.

4) Core team
   - Describe core team profile, size, and development plan.

5) Finances
   - List major cost categories and general funding approach (sending church, partners, giving).

6) Gathering strategy
   - Explain pre-launch gatherings, preview services, and launch Sunday.

7) Health metrics
   - Identify 6–8 indicators of health beyond attendance.

Tone should be faith-filled, realistic, and strategic.
excerpt: Outline a 3-year church plant strategy from vision to launch and early growth.

title: Women's Conference Session Plan
content:
You are planning a teaching session for a women’s conference on [TOPIC]. Create a biblically rich, emotionally honest session.

Include:

1) Session overview
   - Title, key verse, and 2–3 sentence summary.

2) Teaching outline
   - 30–40 minute outline with 3–4 main points and recommended illustrations.

3) Interaction
   - Suggest 1–2 interactive elements (journaling, pair share, response stations).

4) Discussion
   - Provide 5–7 small group questions to process the message.

5) Ministry time
   - Outline a simple prayer/response time.

Use a gentle yet courageous tone that speaks to real struggles and points to Christ.
excerpt: Design a women’s conference session with strong teaching, interaction, and ministry time.

title: Church Merger Integration Plan
content:
You are guiding [CHURCH A] and [CHURCH B] through a merger. Create a [12/18-month] integration roadmap.

Include:

1) Vision and reasons
   - 1 short paragraph explaining why the merger is happening and the hoped-for outcome.

2) Governance and staff
   - Outline steps to unify leadership structures and staff roles.

3) Culture and communication
   - Plan regular communication updates and 4–6 ways to honor each church’s story.

4) Ministry and gatherings
   - Show how ministries, services, and programs will be consolidated or aligned.

5) Timeline
   - Provide a quarter-by-quarter or month-by-month list of key milestones.

6) Care
   - Include ways to pastor people through grief, anxiety, and change.

Tone should be sensitive, transparent, and hopeful.
excerpt: Map out a sensitive, structured integration plan for two churches merging into one.

title: Biblical Counseling Session Guide
content:
You are preparing for a pastoral counseling session with someone struggling with [ISSUE]. Create a simple, gospel-centered session guide.

Include:

1) Understanding
   - 6–8 questions to understand their story and current situation.

2) Scripture
   - 4–6 passages that speak to their struggle with brief notes on each.

3) Truth and hope
   - 5–7 key truths about God and the gospel that can anchor them.

4) Action steps
   - Suggest 3–5 practical, realistic next steps or homework.

5) Prayer
   - Write a short prayer you might pray in session.

6) Referral
   - Note when and how you would consider involving professional help.

Use compassionate language and avoid minimizing pain.
excerpt: Prepare a pastoral counseling session with questions, scriptures, and hopeful next steps.

title: Summer Camp Devotional Series
content:
You are creating a devotional series for youth summer camp with the theme [THEME]. Design a [5/7-day] progression that leads toward a response.

For each day include:

1) Title and scripture
   - Catchy daily title and main passage.

2) Talk outline
   - 5–7 minute teaching outline with 2–3 key points and 1 main illustration.

3) Group discussion
   - 4–6 questions for cabin or small group time.

4) Personal challenge
   - 1 concrete step or reflection for the day.

5) Evening reflection
   - 1–2 prompts for quiet or campfire time.

Keep language teen-friendly and Christ-focused, building toward a clear gospel invitation by the final day.
excerpt: Create daily camp devotionals that build toward a clear, gospel-centered response.

title: LinkedIn Ministry Presence Strategy
content:
You are advising pastors and church leaders on how to use LinkedIn for ministry influence. Create a simple strategy.

Include:

1) Profile
   - 6–8 tips for optimizing headline, summary, and experience to reflect faith and calling.

2) Content pillars
   - Identify 3–4 themes (faith and work, leadership, culture, local community) and give 3–4 post ideas under each.

3) Rhythm
   - Suggest a realistic posting and engagement rhythm (e.g., 2–3 posts/week, 10 minutes/day commenting).

4) Voice
   - Describe the tone (professional, humble, hopeful, non-combative).

5) Connection
   - Provide 5–7 ideas for connecting with local leaders and businesses.

Keep advice practical, avoiding hype or inauthentic tactics.
excerpt: Outline a practical LinkedIn strategy for pastors that connects faith and professional life.

title: Elder/Deacon Nomination Process
content:
You are formalizing the process for nominating and affirming elders/deacons at [CHURCH NAME]. Create a clear, biblically grounded process document.

Include:

1) Biblical basis
   - Summarize key qualifications with references (1 Timothy 3, Titus 1) in 5–7 bullets.

2) Timeline
   - Outline the annual or periodic nomination timeline.

3) Nomination
   - Explain who can nominate, how, and with what information.

4) Assessment
   - List key areas of evaluation and 6–8 sample interview questions.

5) Congregational involvement
   - Describe how the congregation gives input or affirmation.

6) Installation
   - Outline a simple public installation service moment.

7) Ongoing review
   - Note term lengths and review practices.

Tone should be transparent, humble, and serious about character.
excerpt: Define a clear, biblical process for selecting and installing elders or deacons.

title: Multisite Campus Launch Plan
content:
You are planning to launch a new multisite campus of [CHURCH NAME] in [LOCATION]. Draft a high-level launch plan.

Include:

1) Why this campus
   - 1 short paragraph explaining the vision and reason for this location.

2) Timeline
   - Map out stages from announcement to 90 days post-launch with key milestones.

3) Campus pastor and team
   - Describe desired campus pastor profile and core launch team roles.

4) Facility
   - Outline criteria and basic setup needs for the venue.

5) Communication and marketing
   - Suggest 4–6 ways to communicate to existing and new audiences.

6) Launch strategy
   - Explain preview services, soft launch, and grand opening.

7) Integration
   - Note how teaching, worship, groups, and ministries will align with sending campus.

Keep the plan concise, strategic, and anchored in prayer and mission, not just logistics.
excerpt: Outline a strategic, mission-focused plan for launching a new multisite campus.
